{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3606350,"name":"","username":"tech2fin","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/4491bb/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-04-28T18:23:19.283Z","cooked":"

This question has being lingering in my mind and I was not able to find a thread addressing this directly.

In 2025 Reefscape robot programming, we used setpoints and states to manage various levels of the algae subsystem.
In TeleOp, the latency of the human operator was typically long enough to avoid the SW/HW latency differences.
In Autonomous mode, the latency differential became very obvious: setpoints were being updated at the frequency of the scheduler while for example, it took about 2 seconds for the elevator to rise from bottom to top.
Given the time constraints, we ended up resorting to timer-based controls to switch between levels (in contrast to a “real” state machine to manage switching among the states).
It took some experimentation to find the adequate timeout values and this approach worked out just fine.

As I am looking into refactoring and improving the code (command-based) I am searching for alternatives.
I wonder if there is a solution purely at the software level without some feedback from the mechanical system.
I checked andThen() type of decorators but those seem to be an elegant way of constructing properly sequenced commands.

One interesting option would be to add some sensors at critical levels and use that feedback to execute the next command.

Any thoughts, experiences, suggestions?
Aziz

Command Based is what you’re looking for. Specifically, look at the isFinished() method in commands: Commands — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation
The state of the subsystem is the command that is running on it. You specify when it is ready to move onto the next state by specifying the logic (checking sensors) in the isFinished() method, returning true once the command has gotten the subsystem into the desired state and false otherwise.
